comments.body: It looks like we use sys.platform == "win32" elsewhere in the code to determine whether we're on Windows. Do you have a reason why do you use platform.system() == "Windows" instead? If it does not matter, we should use the same test. If it's more robust, we should replace the test in other places as a subsequent PR.

I have no explicit reason for that, just made most sense. I also saw elsewhere in the code (project/__init__.py) that we use `if os.name != "nt":` to determine whether we are on windows.

I think i should research a bit more and find a more scalable way to figure out on what OS we are. Maybe i should take a look at how tensorflow or other major python projects do that?

Maybe an Object or Config File that would contain all resources for every os, like the terminal type, command separator, etc. Or maybe a library that does that.

Seems like tensorflow uses 'platform' quite often. Here their a simple method for windows identification:

```
def _is_windows():
  return platform.system() == "Windows"
```

Not sure if mlflow has a global repository of methods/helpers, but we could code a few OS identifying methods (like the one above) and use these helpers everywhere else in the code. This way if we decide to change the way we identify a OS, we must do so only in one location (helper/global methods).

How does that sound?

https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/b04371bc952f9f9668e862d82db71651fdef8dc6/third_party/gpus/check_cuda_libs.py#L42
Sounds great! Thanks for looking into it. I think we can do that in a followup though and merge this PR as is.
Agree :)
Awesome, merging now, thanks again for the contribution!
Are you in mlflow Slack? @tomasatdatabricks
Yes I am (name is Tomas Nykodym).

comments.body: S3 client already embeds the region -- why was this change needed?

By default, the region name is resolved from AWS credentials on the caller's machine. However, the user may not always want to use the default region when creating SageMaker and S3 resources. We allow the user to specify a region name as an argument to `deploy()`; all boto clients and sessions should use this region name.

However, the current behavior still uses the default region name, which may lead to unexpected behavior.

comments.body:
Having two methods that take a lot of arguments, most of them the same, suggests that there may be an internal abstraction we could build that might simplify/reduce duplication. A lot of the code in these functions does look similar; it may be worth considering if we could simplify here.

I don't have a particular idea in mind, though, so it's cool not to do anything if the resultant code is likely to be more complicated or less easily extensible.
Two slightly odd things, btw. Both the code here and in `update` lookup the endpoint, and seem to wait for some notion of success.
Oops, just noticed that the update code is relevant for the status update stuff, so that's already minimal.
I think attempting to break this apart using additional abstractions may hurt readability and extensibility; the logical path is pretty distinct for each routine.

comments.body: Maybe add the new parameter at the end so as not to break any existing code that depends on parameter order.

Since `_update_sagemaker_endpoint` is an internal method that existing code outside of this module should not depend on, it seems safe to insert the parameter in its current location.  This way, the method's parameters are structured such that all of the arguments that will be passed to the boto3 clients are grouped together.

Would be nice to add a comment linking to the Sagemaker API doc for ModelDataUrl (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/latest/dg/API_ContainerDefinition.html) to help understand why parsing the field this way is valid. An alternative to using `urlparse` here is to directly use the regex from the AWS docs (`^(https|s3)://([^/]+)/?(.*)$`), but fine with doing it this way as well :)
Added a comment linking to the docs. Decided to stick with `urlparse` since `ModelDataUrl` is a valid URL.
